Name: -1_would_party_republicans_one
Representative_Docs:
["I'm a unicorn on here: conservative. Honestly, I think conservatives have the toughest choice to make. Do we completely throw our values down the drain in a last ditch effort to, at best, have a small chance to save the Supreme Court? Do we protest vote for the Republican we *would've* supported, so that the GOP gets a clear message of who we want? Do we compromise and vote for Johnson, in the hopes that he gets Libertarianism (a philosophy quite similar to ours) mainstream? Do we cross the lines and vote for Clinton in the hopes that it destroys the alt right for good, and we come back with a vengeance in 2020?

I honestly don't know yet. I want to support Johnson. I really do. But doing so is becoming more and more of a compromise every day. The guy keeps scooting to the left as we near November. We've been utterly screwed this cycle, and I lay the blame on primarily on Rubio. Had Rubio dropped at the same time as Paul, as he should've, and had we unified around Cruz, we would've had a legitimate shot at making our case to America. But...Rubio's pride got in the way. 

I will not forgive him for it. Paul got out when he needed to. But Rubio? Kasich? Those guys stuck around long enough to let Trump get thin margins of victory in winner-take-all states, sealing our fate. They will **never** get my vote.", 'The GOP gained full control of the Congress in 2010. Since then, they made zero attempts to improve healthcare. That is more than eight years with no plan, and multiple attempts to repeal the ACA.

All the stuff since Trump came into office has been the same. Find a way to dismantle the ACA and take away coverage from millions of Americans.

And, most of the stuff you mentioned has not taken effect. Just the fact that you refer to an "Obama judge" shows you don't understand the law. That case was the industry suing to block the rule from going into effect. The judge must have seen some merit in the case, and who he was appointed by probably has nothing to do with it.

And you do realize that all the criticisms you just made of Obama were the status quo under Bush, right? You can say Obama didn't go far enough, but he didn't create any of those issues. The reason the ACA didn't go further was because they tried to get bipartisan support but amended it to placate the GOP. And, for all that debate and compromise, not a single Republican voted for it.

If Trump's pricing transparency measures actually go into effect, I will give him credit for that. But the GOP, broadly, is doing more to take healthcare away from people than they are to expanding or improving it.', 'A large number of voters (a majority even) will only ever vote for one party. Therefore, to win an election (on top the uneven electorate sizes and so on) you need a candidate that can do one or both of the following:

1 - Convince swing voters to vote for them and their party.

2 - Energise their own supporters to actually vote.

So you are actually only focused on a fairly small percentage of the voting public. And, of course, you are only really concerned about these two groups in the small number of swing states…

So yes, outspoken may be a good thing, but they would need to be very careful about what they are outspoken on…']

Name: 4_russia_ukraine_putin_nato
Representative_Docs:
['I think it is extremely unlikely that there will be even a limited strike against military targets unless the Russian strike looks intentional.  I ***highly*** doubt that the strike was intentional.  A single small strike against Poland that achieves literally no objective other than giving NATO a casus belli to enter the war is such a stupid idea that not even the Russians dumb as dirt commanders would float the idea.

Russia's goals in Ukraine have changed over time as Ukraine has denied them one objective after another.  One goal that has been absolutely consistent for Russia though is to, whatever they do, not get NATO involved.  In fact, keeping NATO from getting involved is the absolute highest priority for the completely obvious reason that Russia's military would be destroyed if NATO joined, and their only recourse would be nukes.

Russia almost certainly didn't attack Poland intentionally, and as a result, NATO will almost certainly not escalate in a violent manner.  NATO "escalation" for this incident will be NATO supplying Ukraine with more weapons of the type that they want.  NATO might use this as an excuse to hand over some weapons that they had previously holding back on, but that's pretty much the extent of the retaliation I'd expect.', "> We couldn’t just devastate Russia’s military and economy in a conventional war and expect them to not use nukes.

Of course you can. NATO is strong enough to fight the war entirely on defence—destroy Russian assets in Ukraine, without any escalation against Russia proper. 

The Soviet Union lost in Afghanistan, badly... they didn't turn to nukes. Putin may try and portray himself as a crazy man with his finger on the button, but that isn't what he is. Once he opens the nuclear box, Russia as a nation is effectively doomed. Even their supporters will turn on them, China and India will cut them off, because **no one wants that box open.** Their invasion of Ukraine would end in humiliating destruction by an enemy they have spent years acting like they could threaten at will. 

Russia is not suicidal. If they're not invaded, they will not choose to destroy everything in order to avoid losing Ukraine. The Russian nation might survive a loss in Ukraine—it would absolutely not survive a nuclear exchange with the west.", ">Reading the BBC report today that about 75% of Russian adults over 40 years old support the war and the number is only 62% for those under 40, regardless Putin has no incentive to stop the war because he maintains the broad support of his people. Russia has subjected its people to horrible conditions for generations, and so despite sanctions, it doesn't really change much for the ordinary Russian people.

Polling in Russia is difficult, due to the authoritarian state. Which is not to say that people don't support the war, but it's hard to know how many and how fervently. 

Suffice to say, Putin doesn't have to worry too much about the people at home and how they feel about him and the war.

The only way this war stops is if either Putin/Russia choose to withdraw, or are forced to through superior arms. 

Without escalating to something like nuclear attacks on Ukraine, it doesn't seem like Russia has the capability to actually win at this point. And even that is suspect - the US has made it clear they would respond to nuclear weapons in Ukraine with overwhelming conventional force such that Russia deploying nukes would lead to a rapid loss, rather than any gains.

The fastest way to stop this war is to give Ukraine the weapons they need to retake and defend all of their territory, including Crimea. Holding back is just going to make the war drag on longer because Ukraine certainly won't surrender, they've made that clear, and Russia shows no signs of giving up"]

Name: 8_trans_gay_gender_lgbt

['Agreed. I think people should be more precise with their language. "We don't really know" ends up being an argument that cannot be proven false and is repeated indefinitely with moved goalposts. When transitioning and gender affirming care saves lives, it is cruel and unreasonable to cut off people who seek it and are already receiving it.

Here's a funny thing: so many of the trans people who did transition after 2016 did so then not because they applied and were rejected, but because they didn't know they could get gender affirming care or that their feelings were gender dysphoria. "Ah, all people dream of being the opposite sex!" "Most of them don't" "wait what" *egg cracking noises. later:* "Oh, THAT was dysphoria?"  


I started transitioning in 2018/2019, but it's not like my dysphoria just cropped up around that time. I looked back over the 26 years I had lived, and realized I had been feeling dysphoria since a young age, and especially since puberty. Why didn't I transition in my teen years? Because even though I hated being a guy and thought girls had to so much better, I didn't think hormone replacement therapy could make me pass as a woman. It does (along with voice training and other things I've done). Heck, I remember therapists, friends, and even a teacher or two asking me if I was trans; I denied it because deep down I feared I couldn't pass.', 'I know a few gay men who have started expressing anti-trans sentiments because "trans people and gay people aren't the same and this focus on trans people is causing harm to gay rights"

Protests influenced John McCain to vote to keep the ACA. 

Protests influenced Jeff Flake to vote for FBI investigations into Kavanaugh's sexual assault allegations. 

Protests in South Korea forced political change in 2016-2017. 


Protests work in a democracy. How they work in oppressive political systems is another questions. I think morale plays an important and often invisible role too. If you're a woman in Poland and you see pictures of the protests and see the crowds you'll feel more empowered and less alone. That can keep you going when things feel difficult. So although that isn't necessarily an "actionable result", it is extremely valuable for driving political change in the future.', 'I don't think the danger is in burning out the protesters, but rather the American public. At some point, they'll just start tuning out the protests. 

The Women's March got a lot of attention, although the message was muddled. Once they start having a protest a week, is anyone going to care anymore? I think most people will just say, "Oh, another protest. They're always protesting about something."

That said, there's not much that can be done about this since there's no central authority that controls protests. It's a tragedy of the commons problem. Every group with an issue is going to protest since that's the cool thing to do and they're all going to drown each other out.

A lot of these protests aren't even Trump-specific. I thought the airport protests were the most effective thus far, because they targeted a Trump-specific issue that had highly visible consequences--people at airports being denied entry into the U.S. But if people are be protesting something that any standard-issue Republican would have done, I don't think the general public is really going to care. They're used to Republicans, after all, most of them have Republicans as governors and representatives in Congress.', ''It's actually pretty easy to argue the BLM protests didn't spread covid. If they did, we should have seen a massive spike in cases a couple weeks after the protests started.

But we didn't. In actual fact, the outdoors is generally quite a safe place in terms of covid spread. Add in masks (and people at BLM protests were overwhelmingly masked up) and you have what we got - large crowded outdoor protests, and no evidence of significant covid transmission.

The whole "oh so social distancing isn't important when it comes to protesting" is just a bunch of bad faith right wing bullshit meant to delegitimize civil rights protesters, but doesn't make sense if you think about it for a minute, as I described above.

In any case, you ignored OP's point. Which is that the BLM protests were for one cause (the right of black Americans not to be extrajudicially murdered by police) while this Ottawa convoy is for another (the right to spread a disease).']

Name: 31_constitution_amendment_states_executive
Representative_Docs:
["But ultimately the way it's written is why it hasn't been amended for 50 years despite rapidly changing times, if you don't count the 27th Amendment which was already pending for 200 years by the time was ratified. It will probably never change again unless one party gets a supermajority control of the House, Senate, and state legislatures. Congress is feckless, law is written in the Supreme Court which is a partisan playground, and the Executive rules by EO. Nothing can change because this is the path of least resistance in the federal government.", 'I'm immediately skeptical of any site that starts out with "Our founding fathers...", and it took a while to find the actual list of proposed amendments.

* A balanced budget amendment
* A redefinition of the General Welfare Clause (the original view was the federal government could not spend money on any topic within the jurisdiction of the states)
* A redefinition of the Commerce Clause (the original view was that Congress was granted a narrow and exclusive power to regulate shipments across state lines–not all the economic activity of the nation)
* A prohibition of using international treaties and law to govern the domestic law of the United States
* A limitation on using Executive Orders and federal regulations to enact laws (since Congress is supposed to be the exclusive agency to enact laws)
* Imposing term limits on Congress and the Supreme Court
* Placing an upper limit on federal taxation
* Requiring the sunset of all existing federal taxes and a super-majority vote to replace them with new, fairer taxes

Most of these are ill-advised, some of them are just straight up nonsense.  It's all just general "Let's dismantle the federal government" proposals, which is at best far-right pandering.  ', '> The U.S. Constitution has been amended 27 times, an average of once every 8.6 years.

While technically true, this is a deceptive statement. The first 10 amendments were written almost immediately after the Constitution was ratified. So more like every 13.6 years for the final 17. But still, that is deceptive, because the amendments came in clusters.

The last amendment was done in 1992, **30 years ago**, but was a semi-stunt, having been proposed in 1789, ratified by 7 states right out of the gate, one more in 1873, and then the rest in 1978-1992. 

The 26th Amendment was done in 1971, **51 years ago**. This lowered the voting age to 18, and was spurred by the fact that 18-year olds were being drafted and sent to Vietnam.

The 25th Amendment was done in 1967, **55 years ago**. This handled presidential succession, and was spurred by JFKs assassination.

The 24th Amendment was done in 1964, **58 years ago**. This prevented poll taxes, and was done in response to the Civil Rights crisis of the mid-60s.

The 23rd Amendment was done in 1961, **61 years ago**. it gave people living in Washington DC the right to vote in presidential elections, a significant oversight, but ostensibly also a civil-rights issue, since over half the city was black.

Since the 27th Amendment was originally proposed in 1789, putting it aside, it has been over 50 years since a constitutional amendment has been proposed. This is a much more dramatic number than the 8.6 "average".']

Name: 32_voting_parties_system_party

["Oh for sure, that's the essence of the first past the post voting style that we currently use for the majority of our elections in the USA - eventually it will come down to what we have today: two roughly equal-performing groups that hold diametrically opposed views continually squabbling for control of a swinging middle.

The ideal solution here would be a well designed multiple-choice voting system. My preference would be STAR for ease of use and lack of explicit bias, but there are many similar systems out there. Understand that both Democrats and Republicans and all their leashed media outlets would defend first-past-the-post voting rabidly, any system that allows for nuanced discussions and shifting alliances would break the power of the parties. Probably good for *the country* but terrible for *the parties*", 'Two party popularity has nothing to do with the parties themselves and everything to do with our voting system. FPTP/winner take all voting means enough leaving their party for a third means neither party can win, so we don’t. 

We need non FPTP/WTA voting like rank choice, star voting, proportional representation. Some of these are already happening in some areas. But the parties themselves lose if this wins so there’s disincentive to pass them.', "Don't get me wrong, the EC is insane and shit, but I don't think the change in the presidential election system will change anything in the two party system. If you look at nations with multi party system, the head of government still regularly boils down to a binary choice. Take for example Germany, for its entire post-war history, every chancellor was either CDU or SPD (use this as an example because I am most familiar with the German system, but I think it is similar in most nations that need coalitions for government, which is the only real system to have multi party systems).

The real change that is necessary to get a mutli party system is  to have proportional seating in Congress, as well as in every state the houes of representatives. Only when they are not voted in directly anymore, but it is ensured that they will be seated in proportion of the electorate votes, you can have a multi party system. The president and in the states the governors will most likely stay a binary choice, as these positions can only be occupied by one person of one party, and it will always be a struggle between the biggest party on the left vs. the biggest party on the right, but due to coalition governments, the presidents and governors will have to implement the will of their junior coalition members that are necessary to lift them into position."]
